componenttextpreview: For the most part, yes. Both in the U.S. and Europe. Some of them are margin enhancing, and I won't get into the specifics. But most of them are margin neutral or better. There are a few exceptions but not many.
componenttext: For the most part, yes. Both in the U.S. and Europe. Some of them are margin enhancing, and I won't get into the specifics. But most of them are margin neutral or better. There are a few exceptions but not many.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alexia Howard with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the 2 acquisitions, Foodstar and Quero. It seems as though Foodstar is getting off to a rocketing good start with the sales growth being at 30%. Quero seems to be solid at from at a 8% to 9% level but obviously not quite as fast as F
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the 2 acquisitions, Foodstar and Quero. It seems as though Foodstar is getting off to a rocketing good start with the sales growth being at 30%. Quero seems to be solid at from at a 8% to 9% level but obviously not quite as fast as Foodstar. I mean does that represent the upside? Is there more upside from the Foodstar acquisition or is that you're waiting to get going on Quero? And what are the biggest sort of surprises or lessons learned from each acquisition so far?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, and let's talk about Quero first. Quero first half it's up over 10% in October, it will be up over 11% in the Q3. You've got to remember in Quero, we spent the first 3.5 months integrating the business. We have not spent marketing. I believ
componenttext: Well, I think, and let's talk about Quero first. Quero first half it's up over 10% in October, it will be up over 11% in the Q3. You've got to remember in Quero, we spent the first 3.5 months integrating the business. We have not spent marketing. I believe we spent about $400,000 in total marketing in the first half of the year on Quero. We were short of capacity particularly in corn processing. And so we are now in the process we just turned television on for the first time ever, the first second week in November, we are just taking the Heinz brand into Quero. We've added capacity. Our supply chain came global supply chain team just came back from the visit to the factory outside of São Paulo and are raving about the opportunities, particularly on passion on tetra Pak  where we can run tetra packs faster than we can run in many parts of our business. So I think in Quero, you will see a substantial increase in second half sales as a function of the marketing investment and a lot of the new items we are putting in place. On Foodstar, my concern on Foodstar is not growth. My concern is how we're going to stay up with it. We grew 30% on the Master brand and Guanghe brand in the first half of the year. October sales were up 69%. November sales are running at about that level, north of 50%. The Shanghai factories come online but it is nowhere near ready yet to handle the kind of growth we are seeing in Foodstar. Foodstar is a function of a lot of things, a lot of new product activity, significant levels of advertising again which we haven't started yet in Quero. We've gone into our third province so in Guangdong, we are in Fujian and we've gone to Zhang. so i think Foodstar we have other thing Foodstar really helped us is also the brand which is the white bean curd market, the bread bean marketing spend and grow this and we're now launching into the red bead current market. We have a lot of new product activity to take us in together 3 segments on soy sauce. It mean, Foodstar is a business, frankly, that every time we have an update with the Chinese team, we take the number up and ask ourselves how we're going to continue to supply and then that I don't mean to be flip on that. That is a concern we have. This business is just growing so rapidly and we are only in 3 provinces. We're hitting on some 200 million people in a country of 1.2 billion. But Quero itself in the second half will grow substantially fast as we infuse marketing. Foodstar will continue its growth in the second half. And as I said at the outset, our emerging market businesses of the second quarter were up 60% organically. They're between 14% to 15% for the first half. I expect our emerging market businesses organically to be up somewhere between 10% and 20% minimally on that growth rate in the second half of the year as we lap the purchase of Foodstar, as we continued to drive significant growth in China, we have a lot of innovation coming in China, a lot of innovation coming in Poland. We have launched cheese sauce and Russia which is doing spectacularly well. This is a product that actually has out used versus ketchup and McDonald's and Russia which we supply. And so there's just a lot of activity in the Emerging Markets and while obviously we do have some concerns about the economies in those markets, if anything I think our growth rate in the second half of the year will be dramatically better on these businesses. This just a lot of activity. The other thing in Quero we've done is we've infused new management capabilities to the business Odie we do not have before, and in fact, interestingly enough, the Brazilian team has been on the phone with the U.S. team giving them insights on how to drive Dipak catch up on how to drive other businesses like they do in Brazil. So I mean I think of those 2 options, we feel pretty sanguine about where we're going.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Thilo Wrede from Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Thilo Wrede from Jefferies & Company.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bill, can you maybe give us a little bit more color on what you're doing differently in Australia these days, what changed from last year and really where is your confidence coming from that the business in Australia will improve in the second half?
componenttext: Bill, can you maybe give us a little bit more color on what you're doing differently in Australia these days, what changed from last year and really where is your confidence coming from that the business in Australia will improve in the second half?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the good news is it has no place to go but up. And it's been so bad, and I will tell you in the second quarter, the bigger hit to the company, in my view, from an unexpected standpoint was in Foodservice. We actually were anticipating the Australian
componenttext: Well, the good news is it has no place to go but up. And it's been so bad, and I will tell you in the second quarter, the bigger hit to the company, in my view, from an unexpected standpoint was in Foodservice. We actually were anticipating the Australian and issues we experienced. As Art Mentioned, we changed the management team in Australia. We are doing an aggressive job of looking at cost, we've shut down the Gary factory which is a processing plant we've had in a Australia for a number of years. We downsized 2 other facilities and reducing the number of SKUs. We have greatly improved our relationship with the 2 retailers there. That's attribute to Nigel Comer who came over from New Zealand to sort of dress up the business in terms of trying to get it fixed. We lap at the end of the third quarter, the discontinuance of tuna by 1 of the 2 major customers last year so we don't have to deal with that after the month of January. So we get a big pickup going forward from that. We've got a lot of innovation coming just a lot more clarity in terms of the focus. I mean the reality on Australia's it almost come to the point fairly material to us going forward because it has taken such a hit. A lot of activity in Australian and I feel much better about the prospects for Australia going forward than I have in several years but the key thing is the improved relationships with the retailers and our ability to start working with them on more efficient and effective promotion activity and the focus on the right brands. We are really renewing our focus in Australia in Infant/Nutrition where we think there's a significant opportunity in the category is doing well. A lot of activity in new packaging, in opportunities to reduce price points, in beans and in soup. And then just a lot of activity across the business. And so I think with the new leadership we just I said to them on a call the other day, I've seen a bounce in her step that I haven't seen the last couple of years. So I think from that standpoint, the second half of the fiscal year in Australia will perform on a relative basis dramatically better and the good news is that our expectations that you've see that we've shared with you in terms of where we think the year will end are not really expecting a lot out of our Australia in the second half.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Maybe if I can ask 1 follow up, I mean just listening to you talk about all the regions, all the different categories compete in, it sounds like everything is already great or is it just about to become really great? And do you have any concerns about you
componenttext: Maybe if I can ask 1 follow up, I mean just listening to you talk about all the regions, all the different categories compete in, it sounds like everything is already great or is it just about to become really great? And do you have any concerns about your business right now?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Sure. I have many sleepless nights. The concerns I have relate to the global economic environment. The concerns I have relate to the productivity initiatives we are doing and will they become a distraction? The concerns I have always relate to the retenti
componenttext: Sure. I have many sleepless nights. The concerns I have relate to the global economic environment. The concerns I have relate to the productivity initiatives we are doing and will they become a distraction? The concerns I have always relate to the retention of our management team, in the businesses where we're doing well like Europe and Emerging Markets and those kinds of businesses, I worry about complacency and people taking it for granted. Yes, there are a lot of areas but I can tell you see low in the second half of the year, our organic sales are going to be up dramatically more than they were in the first half of the year. And the thing that I think people are forgetting in the second half of the year, we lapped 2 big labor situations last year, one in Latin America, one of the U.K. We've got a lot of new product activity coming that we didn't have in the second half of last year. We lap the SG&A where we really started commence spending on Keystone aggressively towards the end of Q3 and all through Q4. We had a lot of additional investments in other areas last year and as Art mentioned, we have obviously have the Brazilian close in the month of April so there's a lot of things going on in the second half of the year. But I don't want anybody to misunderstand my comments. I am not at all sanguine about the prospects for the industry and about our business without a lot of work. We have a good leadership in place now. But I can tell you and you should recognize that with the additional productivity charges which are focus, you should assume I'm not going to detail yet where because employees haven't been talk to but you should assume their focus on our problem businesses. This is going to continue to be an ongoing struggle in an industry right now that's not being helped by the global economy, that is dealing with significant commodity inflation which lessons for us in a relative basis on the second half. I mean, I just give you some perspective. The Foodservice inflation in the second quarter was over 11% and the second half of the year it's about half that. And our pricing, we just took our third increase on Foodservice last week. We'll roll over into the next 6 months Poseidon want anybody to misunderstand my comments. I do feel very good about our emerging market prospects and I think 16% organic growth in the second quarter should not be taken for granted and I think we'll substantially improve on those numbers in the second half given hopefully the no repeat of our labor situation last year and a lot of new product activity and the fact we lap the Foodstar purchase. So there's just a lot of stuff going on. But as the people who work for me, I'm sure will be glad to tell you in a private moment, you should not think we go into these calls with our business units with the big smile on our face.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney with Janney Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jonathan Feeney with Janney Capital Markets.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Bill, I wanted to follow-up on -- you've listed a number of markets in Europe, where volume was up, I mean am I misunderstanding that, looks like volume was reported down 2.9%. Where was the significant volume decline that offsets all of those positive pe
componenttext: Bill, I wanted to follow-up on -- you've listed a number of markets in Europe, where volume was up, I mean am I misunderstanding that, looks like volume was reported down 2.9%. Where was the significant volume decline that offsets all of those positive performance on those countries?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: U.K. and Italy. But U.K. got more price than it did volume. They took significant pricing at the end of Q1 through Q2. And as a result, they have continue to turn around and spent some of that back. But volume was down significantly in response to that, t
componenttext: U.K. and Italy. But U.K. got more price than it did volume. They took significant pricing at the end of Q1 through Q2. And as a result, they have continue to turn around and spent some of that back. But volume was down significantly in response to that, the categories were down. And in Italy, the baby food category has declined pretty significantly year over the last 3 to 6 months and so we saw some volume decline there. We did take some pricing but it was not enough to offset the volume but the U.K. and Italy were basically the only markets in Europe to see volume down for the quarter.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: And as far as -- you mentioned emerging market volume, grow a revenue of 16%, can you give a -- I know you haven't historically want to get into merger market volume but can you give us a sense how that's split between volume and pricing I know there has
componenttext: And as far as -- you mentioned emerging market volume, grow a revenue of 16%, can you give a -- I know you haven't historically want to get into merger market volume but can you give us a sense how that's split between volume and pricing I know there has been some significant price mix issues, currency issues?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. getting a fair amount of price but we also had very strong volume in the quarter. And I think in the second, and let me put it to you this way, price was more than volume. In the second half, I think volume will be the same or close to price. So you s
componenttext: No. getting a fair amount of price but we also had very strong volume in the quarter. And I think in the second, and let me put it to you this way, price was more than volume. In the second half, I think volume will be the same or close to price. So you should just assume more price and volume in the first half. The reason I don't like breaking it out is because these markets move all over the place in the quarterly basis depending on the NPD. But volume was up, price was up and the second half of the year, volume will be up commensurately more than price in the Emerging Markets.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I guess just 1 last follow-up. The reason I ask this is, looking on a stack basis the way you guys reported it, looks like volume kind of a consolidated basis for the company is down something like 7% since 2008. So basically, since before the re
componenttext: Yes. And I guess just 1 last follow-up. The reason I ask this is, looking on a stack basis the way you guys reported it, looks like volume kind of a consolidated basis for the company is down something like 7% since 2008. So basically, since before the recession. And I mean certainly, I understand exactly where the company is going but I'm wondering 3 years from now, is volume going to continue to decline at that rate? Would you expect as we sort of migrate from developed markets into Emerging Markets?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, in fact, you'll see it go at the other way in the second half of this year as Emerging Markets become more and more important, and as we plateau against some of the other businesses. The bulk of the volume decline over the last couple of years has bee
componenttext: No, in fact, you'll see it go at the other way in the second half of this year as Emerging Markets become more and more important, and as we plateau against some of the other businesses. The bulk of the volume decline over the last couple of years has been related to Foodservice in Australia. I mean  Foodservice volume, this is not new news. It's been declining for 3 years. Our expectation for Foodservice where we would see a turnaround in the industry this year and that the structural dynamics that have worked against us so aggressively would reverse. They have not. And so the bulk of that volume decline in Q2 was Foodservice, and to a lesser degree, Australia from a volume perspective. But there is no doubt, Jonathan, that you're going to see a significant shift. I mean one of the things, again, I'm not trying to be Solomonic here and I'm the trying to express the wisdom of the ages, I think we need to all to keep in mind the reason we put so aggressively into these Emerging Markets is because of a recognition on the difficulty of being able to drive sustained growth in some of these businesses going forward. And again, in the second half, you'll see -- I mean the second half of our year is going to be interesting relative to the first half. What you're going to see in the second half for the year is dramatically improved organic sales versus the first half and a higher tax rate than you saw in the first half. So you're going to see almost opposite situation. But Foodservice in Australia but again in my view going forward, lesser on Australia, more in food service is really where the focus has got to be and if I break out Foodservice by the branded piece versus the nonbranded piece, the branded piece is essentially flat and where we are seeing the pressure in food services on proprietary brands that are made specifically for customers where we've lost price leverage because of the environment and the capacity available and in the categories where we don't bring branded leverage. Similar situation exists in Australia, and as I said U.K. volume was down significantly and it goes all over, I think in Q3, you'll be interested to see what U.K. volume is. I'm not going to tell you, but I think you'll get an interesting perspective as we come bank next quarter in the report. But again, there is no doubt that our shift into Emerging Markets was not done on an ad hoc opportunistic basis. It was done strategically and with intent because I will tell you my own view is that the developed world is going to get increasingly difficult in which to operate just because of the concentration of retailers on all these markets. The difficulty in categories, the pressure consumers are feeling, the ethnic and demographic shifts occurring on all these markets. And so going to see us push more aggressively and with greater alacrity into these Emerging Markets because we have to and that's why. So I think nothing we've seen this year other than I will say Foodservice has surprises. Foodservice has disappointed me because I expected the industry to turn, it has not.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Jonathan, the other thing I'd point is the SKU rationalization that we've done over the last few years on a very conscious basis particularly in the developed markets, particularly in places like Foodservice, as we have gotten the focus more and more on o
componenttext: Jonathan, the other thing I'd point is the SKU rationalization that we've done over the last few years on a very conscious basis particularly in the developed markets, particularly in places like Foodservice, as we have gotten the focus more and more on our Top 15 brands. So we tried to call the road herd if you will at some of the smaller Branson get refocused on Top 15 brands which have grown nicely.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: The only one thing I'd remind you, Jonathan, volume declines, we've had 26th consecutive quarters of organic sales growth and we've made some conscious trade-off between price and volume. But again, I come back to my comments that world is pushing aggress
componenttext: The only one thing I'd remind you, Jonathan, volume declines, we've had 26th consecutive quarters of organic sales growth and we've made some conscious trade-off between price and volume. But again, I come back to my comments that world is pushing aggressively into Emerging Markets are going to wake up 1 day and find out that the world left them behind.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Jonathan, we can follow up later today but I'm not showing volume down for the company that far the only way I could get there is if you're including divestitures. So volume actually has been, I think, flat to slightly up if you include particula
componenttext: Yes. And Jonathan, we can follow up later today but I'm not showing volume down for the company that far the only way I could get there is if you're including divestitures. So volume actually has been, I think, flat to slightly up if you include particularly the '08 year. So anyway, we'd be happy to follow-up with you.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Diane Geissler with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Diane Geissler with CLSA.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: I want to ask on the productivity, the new productivity plan, I think the original plan you announced in May, you had a 2.5 year payback. Could you just confirm that you're still on track regarding that and then should we assume sort of a similar payback
componenttext: I want to ask on the productivity, the new productivity plan, I think the original plan you announced in May, you had a 2.5 year payback. Could you just confirm that you're still on track regarding that and then should we assume sort of a similar payback on the new plan given that you're not giving a lot of details and I understand why but if you could help us with what we should think about there?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, to your point, Diane, we are on track with the plan that we laid out. Certainly, the projects we talked about back in May, as I mentioned, there are on track in terms of cost-benefits and timing. The new programs which we will go into much, probably
componenttext: Yes, to your point, Diane, we are on track with the plan that we laid out. Certainly, the projects we talked about back in May, as I mentioned, there are on track in terms of cost-benefits and timing. The new programs which we will go into much, probably should generate an incremental $15 million or so of pretax profit on an annualized basis over time. So we expect a good solid return out on of those programs as well. And more to follow on that later.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. can I just for a clarification on the new products that you announced today in terms of the smaller pack types, you said margin neutral to maybe slightly positive. But is there -- how should we think about the top line impact? Do you report your vol
componenttext: Okay. can I just for a clarification on the new products that you announced today in terms of the smaller pack types, you said margin neutral to maybe slightly positive. But is there -- how should we think about the top line impact? Do you report your volume in tonnage or units? And does that have -- will then have an impact on your volume number on the topline?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Diane, I don't have enough time for me to explain the machinations. It's a dollarized volume basically mac will be glad to take it it's dollarized volume and the impact the top line should be favorably providing that the sales are incrementally that they'
componenttext: Diane, I don't have enough time for me to explain the machinations. It's a dollarized volume basically mac will be glad to take it it's dollarized volume and the impact the top line should be favorably providing that the sales are incrementally that they're gap fillers in terms of places and people we are not reaching, and right now, our portfolio tends to skew more middle upper income. We are very underdeveloped in the dollar stores and so these are opportunities for us to reach a segment of the population that historically, we have underserved and so I think from that standpoint, this should represent some incremental upside for us going forward. I think the other thing is, I also said I want to be clear on this that not all of the items, there are some exceptions to the margin enhancing emerging neutral. I won't get into the specifics but there are a few exceptions to those. But we should make up for that in terms of the incrementality. I Mean we haven't sold beads in this country and I can't even remember the last time we sold beads here and I've been here almost 30 years and I think the last time we sold beans was maybe the '70s or early 80s beans in the U.S. And so we tested and is done very well. We have a whole line of products like that coming. And I think as we get into the third quarter call, we'll be able to specify and detail for you the items. But I think you'll find it very interesting. Frankly, some of them had me scratching my head as we look at it. But the North American company and European companies in particular have gotten my messages regarding my concern over the top line in developed markets and the fact that we do serve this underserved population segments.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Moskow with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Moskow with Credit Suisse.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question had to do about the supply chain. If you look historically, Heinz has not been a very CapEx intensive company. CapEx has been pretty much in line with D&A. We've had examples of other staples companies had supply chain problems. Bill, as you g
componenttext: My question had to do about the supply chain. If you look historically, Heinz has not been a very CapEx intensive company. CapEx has been pretty much in line with D&A. We've had examples of other staples companies had supply chain problems. Bill, as you go through the supply chain and are now closing more facilities, is that increasing the amount of capacity or the amount of utilization that the other lands have to take on in the absence of those? And what have you done that those plans to make sure that they're capable with up-to-date machines to handle the increased load?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, Rob, I'm glad you asked the question. I think you all know how I feel about CapEx in this industry. I think it's been abused over the years. It's been spent needlessly to add capacity and do is it not giving consumers return our shareholders ret
componenttext: Actually, Rob, I'm glad you asked the question. I think you all know how I feel about CapEx in this industry. I think it's been abused over the years. It's been spent needlessly to add capacity and do is it not giving consumers return our shareholders return and haven't held helps consumers. In our case, one of the rules I outlined at the outset of this initiative was I was not simply picking up equipment and moving it from one edifice to another so, in other words, most of this, there are maybe 2 small exceptions. Most of this volume will shift from factories that were grossly underutilized into factories that were slightly underutilized without the need for a lot of CapEx in terms of new equipment. Now there are a few exceptions closing the Gary required us to do some things in New Zealand and moving some things out of a couple of the factories in Australia allowed us, forced us to put some capital in New Zealand which I did not like doing. But I can tell you and I'm sure Art and Meg will tell you in a private moment that this didn't come without a great deal of angst. I hate these kinds of initiatives. I don't like doing them. I think they're abused. I think we are a company that was criticized for that for a number of years. So done 1 of the rules I outlined for everybody was, I was not simply picking up or buying new equipment put in another factory. We could not take the volume and move to a facility that was underutilized or had excess capacity. It was going to be very difficult to convince me to close some of these facilities. That is in, in essence what we have done. In a couple of cases, we that very low utilized factories where we have decided that our customer relationships coming out of those factories or cost to serve customers were not conducive to the kinds of margins and returns we wanted and so we've shifted away from products from a few of those customers from a few of those businesses. And as a result are not really being required to shift much of anything from utilization standpoint. Our CapEx for the first half of the year is up about $53 million to $55 million. Our inventory is up about $130 million and those are the big uses of cash in the first half of the year. Rest assured, that I'm not happy about that and I've made it abundantly clear to my team and the supply chain that this isn't just simply about, gee, I now have, I had 80 buildings, now I have 75 buildings. This is about getting a lot better and more efficient. And I think we'll be there. So the good news for us is while these things are always somewhat distracting, the reality is they have not required us to do anything above the norm to protect the safety and quality of our company and as a consequence, knock on wood, we have not suffered the same kinds of issues that others have.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: The other thing I think that this allows us to do is really focus our time and attention and resources on those remaining plants. So when you've got a very low utilization plants that not helpful from a focus standpoint, so we've got a very stringent bala
componenttext: The other thing I think that this allows us to do is really focus our time and attention and resources on those remaining plants. So when you've got a very low utilization plants that not helpful from a focus standpoint, so we've got a very stringent balanced scorecard in place that we monitor quality, safety, sustainability along with the usual costs and the other measures. So we feel like we've got a very good program in place and by strengthening the focus on the remaining plants, I think that will be good news overall.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can I just ask, do you guys visit the plants frequently to make sure that you've got the safety measures in place? And what kind of process do you have to do that on an ongoing basis?
componenttext: Can I just ask, do you guys visit the plants frequently to make sure that you've got the safety measures in place? And what kind of process do you have to do that on an ongoing basis?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have an ongoing QRMP process. We have the best safety scores of any company in our industry. We review them with the board twice a year. We have a safety group as part of our risk management process. We have a quality group that's headquartered i
componenttext: Well, we have an ongoing QRMP process. We have the best safety scores of any company in our industry. We review them with the board twice a year. We have a safety group as part of our risk management process. We have a quality group that's headquartered in the U.K. but it's our global group that visits every single factory and also spends a lot of time in the new facilities. And I have to tell you I made a comment earlier, our people have just revisited the Carol factory and our coming back raving I mean Carol has something we don't have anything else in the world and that's a biomass generator which we're using excess sugarcane now to fire up in savings a ton of money. But if we can figure out a way to put cornhusker there, we can literally get free energy in our biggest factory. So there's a lot of activity. I will tell you, Rob, and people who have worked for me a longtime know safety and quality are the 2 single issues that I focus our team on all the time. I think employees have the right to expect to work in a safe environment and I think our brands are only as good as the quality of reputation we have and we sit with our board twice a year in the corporate social responsibilities committee and give them a detailed update on this and in my own personal goals, of which I have 4, 25% of my own personal goals are related to quality and safety, so you can be assured that we take this highly seriously. All of this reports under Mike Milone who in addition is operating responsibilities and brings an operating mindset to ensuring that these are areas of the great focus and detail and believe me, this is one of the things that goes through every one of a single productivity initiatives that we approve.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Ferguson with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rob Ferguson with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is just kind of a quick housekeeping question for Art. I guess I do quick math and I know you said originally, you were at $0.05 or $0.75 at the year and it looks like a used a like for like tax rates from last year. It looks like you've already gott
componenttext: This is just kind of a quick housekeeping question for Art. I guess I do quick math and I know you said originally, you were at $0.05 or $0.75 at the year and it looks like a used a like for like tax rates from last year. It looks like you've already gotten about $0.09 this year in tax benefits. So really, I just want to see if you could provide some type of detailed tax estimate for Q3 and Q4, one . And then 2, is there any updated guidance for EPS with FX?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: What we're talking about was for the goals, they are constant currency. So set aside the currency, I think you see where our currency rates are at now, yes, we have gotten, I don't know, $0.07, $0.08 something like that on a year-to-date basis. We've real
componenttext: What we're talking about was for the goals, they are constant currency. So set aside the currency, I think you see where our currency rates are at now, yes, we have gotten, I don't know, $0.07, $0.08 something like that on a year-to-date basis. We've really don't expect to get anything more out of currency over the back half of the year, no. You tell me where the pound and euro go and where the economies go, it's always a tough question. But at this point, we don't expect much from currency in that regard. And as Bill mentioned, from a tax standpoint, we'll actually see a tax rate that is probably in line or slightly higher over the back half of the year certainly as it compares to last year. And as I mentioned, the key is, that for this fiscal year end, frankly, for next fiscal year, we expect to have a mid-20s kind of tax rate.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Katzman with Deutsche Bank.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011

componenttext: Okay. First question is the $1.15 billion in operating cash flow that you mentioned, does that include or exclude the charges for the restructuring and the updated figures there?

componenttextpreview: Excludes. As I said, we'd be $1 billion reported and $1.15 billion excluding the charges.
componenttext: Excludes. As I said, we'd be $1 billion reported and $1.15 billion excluding the charges.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second, I think you had mentioned, if my memory is correct, on the acquisitions Quero and Foodstar that those would be kind of earnings neutral for the year. Is that kind of still how you see it or are those actually contributing now versus and that
componenttext: Okay. Second, I think you had mentioned, if my memory is correct, on the acquisitions Quero and Foodstar that those would be kind of earnings neutral for the year. Is that kind of still how you see it or are those actually contributing now versus and that's kind of offsetting some of the other challenges?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think that's a fair question. In the first half they contribute. We'll spend a lot of marketing money in the second half on Quero. We didn't spend any of the first half until we got the business faster where we wanted. And I think for the year, I t
componenttext: Yes, I think that's a fair question. In the first half they contribute. We'll spend a lot of marketing money in the second half on Quero. We didn't spend any of the first half until we got the business faster where we wanted. And I think for the year, I think you should assume, Eric, they will be neutral to slightly better.

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Last thing, at the Analyst Day, you gave the fiscal '13 guidance. I mean are you kind of withdrawing that or at this point, it's just too volatile relative to comment? How do we think about that $3.60 to $3.70 number?
componenttext: Last thing, at the Analyst Day, you gave the fiscal '13 guidance. I mean are you kind of withdrawing that or at this point, it's just too volatile relative to comment? How do we think about that $3.60 to $3.70 number?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right now, I'm not saying anything about it. I don't see it, it's just way too early to draw any conclusions in terms of making any changes. So right now, I think you should assume that we're holding to that number until I tell you something else. But we'
componenttext: Right now, I'm not saying anything about it. I don't see it, it's just way too early to draw any conclusions in terms of making any changes. So right now, I think you should assume that we're holding to that number until I tell you something else. But we're not going to give you guidance until May and we never do, Eric, and you know that. I get press the CAGNY, I get pressed in the Q3 call and it's so volatile world and things are changing. So in May, we'll give the updated guidance. But right now, I just don't see any reason to move off that guidance but I want to be clear that, that doesn't mean we will or we won't. I'm just saying that right now, it's just way too early. And our second half is going to be pretty good, I think. And so I hope I'm not proven wrong but certainly based on where I expect this to be from an earnings standpoint sequentially better in Q3 and Q4 and where I expect us to be from a sales standpoint sequentially better and good organic sales in the second half. And where I expect this to be in Emerging Markets and U.K. perspective. I just think that right now, it's just too early to make any changes to it.

What's different this time versus then? Is it more breadth of products? Your ability to penetrate different channels or maybe you can just elaborate on that?

headline: H. J. Heinz Company, Q2 2012 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we never did it. The U.S. has been very slow to react. And so you'll see most of it's starting in the third quarter, late in the third quarter. And so there's nothing different about it. It's just it has taken us longer in the U.S. to get to where we
componenttext: Yes, we never did it. The U.S. has been very slow to react. And so you'll see most of it's starting in the third quarter, late in the third quarter. And so there's nothing different about it. It's just it has taken us longer in the U.S. to get to where we need to be and you'll see a flurry of activity in Q3 that, in my view, and the U.S. feel about my view shouldn't happen in Q2 so there's really nothing different about it, Jason. It's just a delay.

componenttext: Yes, that's the way we are viewing it. So yes, sort of mid-20-ish this year and next. Thank you, all, for participating. I know it's a tough time of the year. I do hope that you appreciate the fact that we spend the time that we do. As you know, there's never been a question asked than we won't answer. There's never a topic brought up we won't addressed. I have an opinion on everything including the Steelers and the bangles if anybody's interested. so have a happy Thanksgiving and a happy holiday and we continue to appreciate your interest in the company and your patience and forbearance with us.
